name: NPR
text:
RT @npratc: Right-wing extremism is on the rise in the U.S., fueled by a combination of the pandemic, protests and President Trump's rhetoric. How does this play into the Michigan kidnapping plot? We'll take a look today on #NPRConsiderThis.
https://t.co/NOQsqHLfVB

name: NPR
text:
Nearly all of President Trump's climate rollbacks have been challenged — and several are likely headed to the Supreme Court.

If Amy Coney Barrett is confirmed, it could have a major impact on the government's ability to fight climate change.
https://t.co/QC7WM4AiBz

name: NPR
text:
As the pandemic continues, parents and caregivers who are homeless find themselves facing an impossible decision: Work to try to escape homelessness, or quit their jobs to help their kids with online learning.
https://t.co/1R9VPPzqD0

name: NPR
text:
President Trump referred to Sen. Kamala Harris as a "monster" on Thursday, a continuation of his pattern of denigrating women — especially Black women.

He has previously reserved the term "monster" for terrorists, murderers and major natural disasters.
https://t.co/Guki2oPwDP

name: NPR
text:
For years, the Supreme Court has largely ducked Second Amendment cases.

But if the Senate confirms Amy Coney Barrett—who seems to have an even more conservative position on the issue than Justice Scalia did—it could spark a big shift on gun regulations.
https://t.co/En9AZyQ0bz

name: NPR
text:
NEW: A federal judge has blocked Texas Gov. Greg Abbott's plan limiting voters to one absentee ballot drop-off site per county, saying it places undue burden on older and disabled citizens.
https://t.co/FBDDsBERSh

name: NPR
text:
China has joined a global effort to ensure fair and equitable distribution of a COVID-19 vaccine. The Trump administration refuses to participate — partly because it's co-led by WHO, which the White House calls "corrupt."
https://t.co/9fbRNSke4s

name: NPR
text:
"The Haunting of Bly Manor" is here.

It may not be as chilling as "The Haunting of Hill House" — but it is ultimately more satisfying, our critic writes, and it whets the appetite for more future installments.
https://t.co/g0OtnYWVpB

name: NPR
text:
When a firestorm hit the town of Malden, most people lost their homes. The post office, library and town hall were leveled. Residents consider it a miracle that no one died.

The town's evacuation plan — created 3 years ago — may have made the difference.
https://t.co/ujALgKQGIN

name: NPR
text:
A judge has allowed Derek Chauvin, the former Minneapolis police officer charged with murder in the killing of George Floyd, to leave the state while he awaits trial due to "safety concerns."
https://t.co/ajxj6zXGIl

name: NPR
text:
Outside groups supporting Joe Biden's campaign are spending $152 million on TV ads in the final stretch of the campaign. That's compared to $56 million by pro-Trump outside groups.
https://t.co/0sj2RAS9ko

name: NPR
text:
Spain's national government has declared a state of emergency in the Madrid region amid a rise in coronavirus cases. The move allows it to impose new lockdown rules despite objections by local officials.
 https://t.co/0zKHI0tpUc

name: NPR
text:
Climate change is increasing the length and intensity of fire season around the globe. But how wildfire smoke affects people's health long-term isn't fully understood yet.
https://t.co/JEY7BgjTH0

name: NPR
text: Foxtrot the dog is reportedly very happy that the agency he represents — the U.N. World Food Programme — has fetched the Nobel Peace Prize. https://t.co/L9mNUIWgeo

name: NPR
text:
Many opponents of solar farms worry they'll replace more traditional farmland.

But some people are finding ways to make the two work together — like Julie Bishop, who grazes her flocks of sheep at solar sites.
https://t.co/bSjDoxTS5w

name: NPR
text:
Desperate to emigrate, a father of 3 in Beirut says he would sell his house and belongings in a heartbeat if there was any certainty of successfully making the dangerous sea crossing to Cyprus.

"But I'm terrified my children would drown on the way."
https://t.co/Gis3c1czhU

name: NPR
text:
The president ignored the advice of experts and failed to take precautions against the virus. With his infection, some critics were probably tempted to conclude he got what was coming.

But many faith leaders warn against rejoicing in another’s suffering. https://t.co/H30kBiGqtU
